A suffocating exercise in not-fun. This is the first Lacerda I've played, and it will be my last. The theme barely makes any sense - a cockamamie hodgepodge of collectors, VIPs, influence tracks, fame tracks, reputation markers, executive actions - the whole thing is an absolute mess and misses out tons of storytelling opportunities and refinement. Maybe the designer could have actually spoken with some people who work in the museum and galleries sector? (I did for 15+ years - this game is a terrible exercise in real world modelling, one of the worst I've ever come across) Poor application of subject matter aside, there's just no ah-ha moments, no elegance, no joie de vivre. There's a streamlined game here, but no gameplay - and the difference is fundamental to why we play games. The puzzles are clever, but tired (racing to fill columns for end of point scoring, etc.) and the strategy simulates something much deeper than it actually is. It's a boring, obtuse, mechanical slog with a half-thought of a setting tagged on, a slot machine wrapped in tinsel. By the end of the game you've achieved very little - you've bought and sold some cardboard art, and wasted three and half hours of your life.

While I sort of admire Vital Lacera's continually-the-same-game design chops, I think that most of his game designs (and fans) are confusing complexity of mechanics and crowded decision trees for depth and/or elegance. They tend to be a mis-mash of far too many mechanics and individual parts, with many of them feeling that they were simply tacked on to add processes to the game design. His inelegant designs feature too many, poorly thought through mechanics that are more complex than they need to be, and wind up putting work before fun.

His games seem to me ... as an award-winning visual designer of 25 years ... to lack any trace of having all the unnecessary design cruft removed. It's almost as though he tries to add too many moving bits into his designs, and then add the kitchen sink as well, in an attempt make his designs feel "heavy" or important when, in fact, they are only adding unnecessary complexity, fiddliness, and that slow the game down too much. That results in players having to focus on the mechanics of a game, more-so than the consequences of the decisions they make. To quote another BGG user ...


Quote:
I [am] the first person to advocate for the less-is-more design approach, which is driven by elegance above all else, and which has been emulated by numerous brilliant designers. It is clear to me that Vital doesn't share that design thesis .... There is so much gratuitous complexity [in Lacerda's designs] for complexity's sake, that I find the experience[s] difficult to enjoy.
That sums it up really well.

My own ratings of his games to date would probably look something like this: Vinhos > CO2 > Kanban. Vinhos I enjoyed playing when I first tried his designs, but still only occasionally. CO2, on the other hand, is a game that I merely a strong "meh" ... I could take it or leave it, but would rather not ever play it again, despite outstanding visual design and theme. And Kanban? I actively and quite strongly dislike Kanban, a game I've been known to refer to as a "hot mess of mechanics that is inelegant, too long, and far to complex for what it is trying to achieve" (much like how I feel about the game Bruxelles 1893).

I had read a long time ago on the forums that The Gallerist was going to (finally) be a more medium-weight game, and have that polish and elegance that seem to be generally lacking in his other titles. That rumour, plus my love of art and the art world, got me really excited for the game. Then came the word that this wasn't the case, this was another heavy one is his usual wheelhouse, a game without question that followed his overly burdened and obtusely complex design patterns and apparent inability to simplify and remove mechanics that should probably be removed to improve flow and elegance.

But, as I said, I am an art lover, I publish an art magazine, paint competently, know many artists, collect art, etc. I had some hope that despite it's complexity, The Gallerist's theme would help me feel better about the complex grinding gears Vital's games seem to feature. Both in terms of the weight of games I like and my own interests outside gaming, I should be the target audience. I often deeply enjoy heavy games (when they are elegant designs). I enjoy games that make me smile and grin while I play them (Snowdonia, Keyflower, Inhabit the Earth, Power Grid, hell, I smile when playing Troyes). I never seem to do that when playing Vital's designs.

I played a four player game of The Gallerist as my first go ... probably not the best number for this game which, after thinking it through, would probably be best at three players ... enough conflict and interaction, without slowing the game down with the overly complex and game-slowing "bumped actions" rules. Even so, with rules lookups and some fiddliness, we managed to knock out a game in three hours. A great group of gamers played, so that always helps. So what do I think after one game?

Vinhos > CO2 > The Gallerist (provisionally) || Kanban.

I'm left generally disappointed (not unexpectedly) after the first game. It's another inelegant Vital design, ponderous, heavy (apparently) simply for the sake of being heavy. There is too much superfluous stuff that could have been removed to make the game smoother and flow better, too much complexity that hides the real essence of what this game's theme is fundamentally about ... run a gallery, buy art, sell art, profit and prestige. It could have been more elegant if the actions and gameplay had been better thought through and ruthlessly pared down. That would have increased the fun and lowered the mental work required to understand the mechanics, so that the strategy and depth of play were the focus. The end-game scoring is a mess of complexity that strikes me as one of the most inelegant scoring flows I've recently encountered in any game. And it doesn't help that there is a contradiction in the rulebook versus the board's scoring track about whether or not to score sold art versus hanging art first, though I'm not sure that it matters score-wise which one is scored first in any case.

Even more unfortunate, however, is that I can't make up my mind if the scoring mechanic is more inelegant than the whole international market/buying actions, which seems to me to be the least elegant and most "tacked on" mechanic in the whole game. Wow. That whole set-up, with it's myriad of randomized bonus tokens that takes too much work to think through how each unique one might affect your long term prospects and end-game scoring. It is also a clear warning sign to me of a designer's inability to clarify and simplify their design, so that each piece of the whole works better and more smoothly, and the consequences and inter-connectedness of each player choice are clearer and more easily identified and understood. There is also no reason the gallery spaces need a lobby plus the gallery, that whole mechanic could have been simplified. Finally, the ability to be able to move meeples out of other people's galleries is, I find, simply a mechanic that was added to the game to complicate the game for no apparent reason except to add to player interactivity.

The visual design is very nice (that's my job, btw, so I appreciate elegant visual and information design) but the gameplay itself isn't a clean design. There are too many moving pieces again to get a handle on the mechanics that allow you to focus on playing the game, rather than the game playing you.

For example, in The Gallerist, here's what I mean about simplifying to make game flow better: The design would have worked just as well and far more smoothly if, when you are bumped from one of the four spots on the board, you simply get a specific "bonus" for each of those four spaces, and you move your player marker back to your gallery. Money, prestige, increase and artist's reputation etc. Simpler and more elegant and smoother game flow.

After years of thinking about the game, I've decided that this isn't a game I will ever bother trying again.

I didn't find it anywhere near as enjoyable as other, heavier games I have been introduced to in the meantime such as 1846, which is a far, far better designed and elegant game. Plus as I've been moving into my later-50s, I find myself reducing my collection to gems I absolutely love ... there's no room on the shelf anymore for fiddly, complex, work>fun games that aren't elegant and deep that I don't absolutely love playing (I've gone from a collection of 1,000+ to 350 to "only" 80 in the past ten years).

I would love to see a design in the future from Vital that is far more polished and less complex. I would have liked to see Vital have designed this game so that it was meant to be played in 90 minutes. I'd like to see him ask himself, as all of us designers must do in the course of any type of design, what could he remove from a design to make that game cleaner, more elegant, and flow better. But maybe he simply can't do this type of game design?

However, if Rosenberg can create Merkator (which I enjoy) or the lighter delightful game that is Patchwork, surely Vital can recognize and perhaps finally try to break out of his unfortunate "kludgy-heavy" design patterns. A medium weight, elegant mechanic game from Vital would be a must-have, I suspect.

Even more, in my fantasy land of "what-if?", I would have absolutely loved to see what The Gallerist could have been if it had been designed by someone like Tony Boydell, Richard Breese, Mac Gerdts, or the brilliant Reiner Knizia (whose masterpieces include Tigris & Euphrates, Samurai, and the simplest but most elegant art-related game ever made, Modern Art), or even what it would have liked like in the hands of a designer I run hot and cold on, such as the "point-salad king" Stefan Feld.

The Gallerist is another (failed) case of complexity in mechanics pretending to be a deep/elegant game. The art/gallery theme actually does work, but the game overall fails to be elegant or fun, sadly, as much as I really wanted to really love it. It is, thankfully, a better game than Kanban, but only by the barest of considerations.

P.S. This is the only game that when I look at my Geekbuddy ratings, I wonder what game those folks were actually playing, because it sure wasn't the same game I was playing. 8? 9? Clearly some sort of medication was messing with their judgements.

Likes:
+ We are running art galleries = yay!
+ Money as victory points, simple and works, aids theme.
+ Main board is very clear

Dislikes:
- Kickout -> disrupts flow of the game, adding a lot of length. Often players haven't considered what they will do before kickout thus inducing further analysis.
- Sidelined -> this occurred in my last game where after I took an action causing a kickout, the other 3 players also proceeded to kick each other out meaning 7 actions occurred until my next turn, not only are you are falling behind but this is boring to boot.
x Collusion -> two players can either explicitly or implicitly co-operate, we saw an artist bumped up to masterpiece from nowhere in the space of two (+kickout actions) turns. I'm not sure you can prevent this, as players could combo to buy the two works of art first then promote them.
- International auction and reputation matrix feels tacked on in turns of theme.
- Bonus tiles in the reputation section seem paramount. Person with most of these seems to win. They are additional scorers as well as triggering bonus resources in game.
- Overall the theme didn't quite come through despite the interesting visuals. This is purely personal, I find Lacerda's other titles to have strong thematic elements ie Lisboa, Kanban etc.

Without question the most exquisitely produced board game to ever hit my table. The board conveys oodles of information, but the layout is very clean and logically organized, and the crisp graphic design adds to the overall aesthetic without creating distraction. From a gameplay perspective I find that the strategies are very delicate, and hinge on a specific order of operations, which is not a criticism in itself, but turns into one due to the kicked-out actions. While being strategically fascinating, these actions too often interrupt game flow and force players to constantly piece back together their next few moves in a manner that is more frustrating than satisfying. Instead of adding a tactical level of player interaction, they create a frustrating downtime issue, and exacerbate the game's overall length problem. Overall, despite the slow and methodical gameplay, each and every decision provides a satisfying crunch.

Like many of Vital's games, I like many parts of it, but the game ends up being both too complex and too circular for my tastes. Too many ways to do the same thing, and everything affects too many things, and too many of these things are too small. I feel like I'm just not the target demo.

Played a solo game of this. The rules were pretty tough to get through. The core structure of the game is mostly straightforward worker placement but introduces two types of special actions. I've heard the game described as "simple to learn but hard to master". It is definitely simple to play but hard to master. The action spaces are all pretty involved though and the game is very procedural. For example, buying a piece of art involves 7 steps none of which are complicated in isolation, but the whole process requires following the action reminder card very closely step by step.

As a solo game it plays great. The AI is just a simple dummy player that moves in a circle and is basically a timer. There is a lot to think about in the game and it definitely takes a game or two to even understand what you should be trying to do. The option space is large and complex but honestly not too bad. Enough to keep you exploring for awhile but not so overwhelming that you won't be able to eventually start figuring things out. The game doesn't seem very interactive to me as far as worker placement goes - the interaction there actually seems like it would be a little forced and irrelevant. The interaction is much stronger in denying scoring opportunities and competing for shared goals, and I like that.

Overall I think the game is interesting. It reminds me a lot of Snowdonia in the sense that the core framework is lightweight while the strategies are nuanced. Unlike Snowdonia I prefer the theme here (although it is still quite abstract) and I think the mechanics here are much more compelling. Solid game for me right now that I need to play a few more times to get a final verdict on rating-wise, but definitely a keeper

EDIT: Some slight regret for getting rid of The Gallerist. Vital Lacerda's games are far from elegant, and this is no exception. However, the scoring works really well here and the procedures aren't too bad. There are lots of bad parts though - like the worker placement thing

Like Lacerda’s other games, The Gallerist is a tight action efficiency puzzle where you’re trying to snowball your resources into points by way of a few fairly involved actions.

The game is more streamlined than other Lacerda’s, with it being focused on getting money by buying and selling artwork. The question in my first game of the Gallerist was very rarely whether you should, but whether you could. That said, like most Lacerda games, repeat plays unlock far more strategic depth than first impressions, so I’ll look forward to trying it again.

Clever economic euro that unfortunately feels streamlined to fault leaving little moments of excitement to be found in its dry optimization puzzle. While it's interesting to figure out at first, the worker movement puzzle quickly becomes samey as you tiredly repeat the looping "do x to do y to do z" sequence of moves while min/maxing the benefits of the bonus tiles, the influence track, the executive actions, and the kick out actions throughout the game with little variation, which is made worse by the game's slow pacing. There's nuance to be found in the various bonuses and the artist stock market both in game and between games, but it isn't enough to overcome the repetitive nature of the game to make me want to play it again.
More plays of this has me warming up to the design, I still find it samey but there's enough depth in optimizing your usage of the influence track and the scoring tiles combined with the other aspects of the game that it winds up being a puzzle that holds up much better on repeated plays than I anticipated.
And so I ended up becoming cold to this design again. Really my issue comes down to the scoring, almost every game has been won by the player that went to the International Market space first and more often than the other players to the point the meta I've played in warped around that space more than the other actions in the game. Gaining the column bonus at the end of the game alone is enough to push you ahead of the other players (provided you're keeping up with them in the other areas) for the win, having tempo control over the scoring tiles creates to big of a point swing by either scoring you huge or denying your opponent their optimal scoring, and while often minor winning the auction for the painting at the end can yield a strong swing in points. To the game's credit, it's difficult to pull that off while maintaining parity with the other players and you can just as easily deny them the benefits, so it's certainly balanced but just not the type of enjoyable experience I was looking to get out of this game.

I definitely do not agree with the majority opinion about this being the “approachable” Lacerda game, or perhaps my brain is wired differently because I actually found this incredibly obtuse, unthematic, and difficult get into. When comparing it to something like Kanban EV, the objective of what you’re trying to accomplish feels a lot more opaque to me, plus there’s heaps more moving parts and game-y rules to conceptualize. The rulebook also most definitely didn’t help as the way it's formatted seems to prefer less clarifications and examples for the sake of fitting particular sections nicely into a single page.

As usual with Lacerda’s games, all the different elements and actions mesh together to create an intertwined and brain-burning optimization puzzle. Only four locations to choose from with eight possible actions to take, but a lot of interconnectivity and nuance between all of them. Once you manage to sequence your moves correctly and keep a good momentum going by getting the maximum efficiency from each action and chain various bonuses together, the game can feel super rewarding. The puzzle has some enjoyable moments, but this a game where the juice is not really worth the squeeze for me.

The downsides of the game for me are that while I appreciate the kicked-out actions since they do add a lot more depth to the game and knowing how to get the maximum benefit out of them by using your influence is a fascinating part of the puzzle… It's just that this added crunchiness unfortunately comes with the expense of the game flow. When all players are constantly taking actions out of turn, the game gets a bit clunky as players lose track of where the turn order actually goes, which happens frequently. Especially since a lot of the actions also come with so many small procedural steps to follow and it’s easy to forget some of them, making the experience rather fiddly.

There is a reason for having the phrase “it is a Lacerda” in boardgamers lingo. The games by this designer are very complex euros, with the complexity rooted in the theme.

The Gallerist is probably one of the best designs by Lacerda, and certainly the one I enjoyed the most: lots of interlocking mechanics, and yet the theme emerges somewhat among all the actions and bonus actions. It is really a great game. But it is also a pain to explain, with lots of details to remember.

There was a time in my life as a gamer, 10 years ago (maybe even less that that), in which I would’ve fallen in love with a game like this. I would’ve rated it a 9 or even higher. Now I am getting older, more disenchanted about the chance to play these long meaty euros enough with experienced players, and even more prone to fatigue when I play.
Furthermore, I tend to value more the games I can play with my family.

For these reasons, the rating is toned down. In spite of the fact that I really liked my first play, that I am looking for more of it, and that my gamer-sense is tickling...

Kurz: Ein leichterer Lacerda? Auf jedenfall wurden Thema und Mechanik gut miteinander verschmolzen.

Langform:
The Gallerist ist ein komplexes (für Lacerda eher mittelschweres) Strategiespiel, das Wirtschaft, Kunst und Einfluss auf faszinierende Weise miteinander verwebt. Als Galeristen managen die Spieler Künstlerkarrieren, kaufen und verkaufen Kunstwerke und ziehen Besucher in ihre Galerien. Der Mechanismus basiert auf einem Aktionssystem mit cleverem "Folgen-/Verdrängungsbonus", das interessante Interaktionen erlaubt. Die Präsentation ist – typisch für Lacerda – erstklassig: hochwertige Komponenten, stilvolles Design und eine thematische Tiefe, die sich besonders im fortgeschrittenen Spielverlauf entfaltet. Wer Freude an verzahnten Systemen und ökonomischem Denken hat, wird hier voll auf seine Kosten kommen. Neueinsteiger in das Genre oder Gelegenheitsspieler werden wahrsch. an der hohen Einstiegshürde scheitern. Es ist eines der Spiele, die man öfters spielen sollte, um den vollen Spielspaß raus zu kitzeln. Aber wir waren positiv überrascht, das wir in nicht mal 2 h fertig waren (zu 3.).

PRO:
+anspruchsvolles, thematisch dichtes Spiel
+interessantes, unverbrauchtes Thema
+exzellente Materialqualität und Artwork
+innovative "Verdrängungs"-Mechanik
+hoher Wiederspielwert durch variable Elemente und Strategiewege
+tiefe strategische Entscheidungen
+trotz Komplexität, ist Mechanik nachvollziehbar

Neutral:
-Für ein solch komplexes Spiel, gar nicht so lang
-Downtime ist bei Grüblern möglich, aber durch Verdrängung ist man immer involviert

KONTRA:
-Sehr hohe Einstiegshürde
-Verdrängung sorgt für etwas Unübersichtlichkeit bei der Reihenfolge
-Kaum Platz für Fehler in der Strategie

Don't let the game's weight scare you from giving it a go . . . or you may be missing out on a gem. Playing two handed solo, I was able to breakup several different afternoons, to try out every action. By the third/fourth repeated action of all four locations, intermediate scoring, rules caveats, etc., I was able to no longer refer to the rulebook/player aid (which are amazingly done by the way!) and recall by the amazing iconography that has all the rules you need to understand the steps.

Everything is clicking in place for me and this game feels more like a slightly heavier game than Agricola. My first game of that took 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 to process the rules with simulating a two player game solo to learn it. The Gallerist, I've spent about 4 to 4 1/2 hours, and my game is nearing the end. I suspect each game the playing time will decrease. My goal is to enjoy it in about 60 to 75 minutes at 2 player (my only player count I play games at or solo). If any are on the fence, this is not as intimidating as it's made out to be. Quite honestly, I only made a couple of set up mistakes that I noticed along the way and also only a couple of mistakes in gameplay. This was a relatively easy game to learn/play (at least to me).
